name: Steppe Agama
description: It has a relatively large head and a slightly flattened body. Dorsally, it is brownish to gray-brown, ventrally whitish. In excitement, males’ undersides turn vivid blue to gray-black. Both sexes can change color based on ambient temperature and physiological state.
spread_note: From the Caspian Sea eastward to northwestern China and southward to Afghanistan
food_note: Insects and other invertebrates, occasionally soft plant parts (flowers, fruits, fleshy leaves)
image_alt: Steppe agama, photo: Petr Velenský, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 29–31 cm, including tail 18–19 cm; weight up to 50 g
reproduction: Females lay 3–18 eggs two to three times per season; incubation lasts about 2 months.
attractions: Males display their blue coloring from elevated spots on bushes to attract females and warn rivals away from their territory. Agamas also retreat to bushes during the day’s peak heat to avoid overheating on hot sand or rocks.
breeding: One steppe agama passed through Prague Zoo in 1951, but consistent breeding began in 2012, when the first offspring hatched.
